elements.content: A new mixed-ligand three-dimensional metal−organic framework is reported, where one component, meso-iminodisuccinic acid, is formed in-situ by the dimerization of aspartic acid under solvothermal conditions. The presence of a rigid pillaring co-ligand renders the framework truly porous and robust to guest loss.
elements.clean_text: A new mixed-ligand three-dimensional metal-organic framework is reported, where one component, meso-iminodisuccinic acid, is formed in-situ by the dimerization of aspartic acid under solvothermal conditions. The presence of a rigid pillaring co-ligand renders the framework truly porous and robust to guest loss.

elements.content: This work highlights the distinct reactivity of Zn with the amino acid aspartic acid in the formation of metal−organic frameworks. Under solvothermal conditions with Ni, Co, and Cu, the aspartate is retained; however, with Zn, the aspartate dimerizes to form iminodisuccinic acid and is encapsulated in the final product, [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)]·guest
elements.clean_text: This work highlights the distinct reactivity of Zn with the amino acid aspartic acid in the formation of metal-organic frameworks. Under solvothermal conditions with Ni, Co, and Cu, the aspartate is retained; however, with Zn, the aspartate dimerizes to form iminodisuccinic acid and is encapsulated in the final product, [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)]⋅guest

elements.content: Amino acid-derived extended metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) are of significant topical interest due to their inherent chirality and the ready low cost availability of the enantiomerically pure starting materials. If the enantiopurity is retained in the extended MOF, this would generate chiral materials which are highly desirable for applications such as enantiomeric separation and asymmetric catalysis. However, simple two-component systems based upon amino acids and metal centers are generally dense, lacking any accessible pore voids. This arises due to the flexibility in the amino acid backbone and in the preferred mode of binding to metal centers, via formation of five-membered N,O chelating metallocycles, with bridging metal centers achieved by binding of the second oxygen of the carboxylic acid functionality. To generate porosity in MOFs, rigid organic linkers are commonly employed, usually consisting of coordinating functional groups bridged by one or more phenyl rings (e.g., 4,4′-bipyridyl or terephthalic acid). The inherent lack of flexibility within these ligands can prevent efficient dense packing, hence favoring the formation of open frameworks, when suitable connectivity is imposed by the metal ions. However, enantiopure rigid linkers are not generally naturally occurring and require complex multistep synthesis. A more economical approach is to use a multicomponent system, where chirality is imposed by enantiopure ligands, such as amino acids, and porosity enforced by extending rigid linkers. We and others have successfully applied this approach to generate enantiopure porous MOFs and have demonstrated how these materials can be useful in separation and catalysis. Herein we report synthetic work targeted at the formation of Zn analogues of the [Ni2(l-asp)2(bipy)] and [Cu2(l-asp)2(bipy)] systems, where rigid M(l-asp) layers are separated by 4,4′-bipyridyl linkers of variable length and encounter the reactivity of the amino acids, which determines the nature of the final product.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Amino acid-derived extended metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are of significant topical interest due to their inherent chirality and the ready low cost availability of the enantiomerically pure starting materials. If the enantiopurity is retained in the extended MOF, this would generate chiral materials which are highly desirable for applications such as enantiomeric separation and asymmetric catalysis. However, simple two-component systems based upon amino acids and metal centers are generally dense, lacking any accessible pore voids. This arises due to the flexibility in the amino acid backbone and in the preferred mode of binding to metal centers, via formation of five-membered N,O chelating metallocycles, with bridging metal centers achieved by binding of the second oxygen of the carboxylic acid functionality. To generate porosity in MOFs, rigid organic linkers are commonly employed, usually consisting of coordinating functional groups bridged by one or more phenyl rings (e.g., 4,4'-bipyridyl or terephthalic acid). The inherent lack of flexibility within these ligands can prevent efficient dense packing, hence favoring the formation of open frameworks, when suitable connectivity is imposed by the metal ions. However, enantiopure rigid linkers are not generally naturally occurring and require complex multistep synthesis. A more economical approach is to use a multicomponent system, where chirality is imposed by enantiopure ligands, such as amino acids, and porosity enforced by extending rigid linkers. We and others have successfully applied this approach to generate enantiopure porous MOFs and have demonstrated how these materials can be useful in separation and catalysis. Herein we report synthetic work targeted at the formation of Zn analogues of the [Ni2(l-asp)2(bipy)] and [Cu2(l-asp)2(bipy)] systems, where rigid M(l-asp) layers are separated by 4,4'-bipyridyl linkers of variable length and encounter the reactivity of the amino acids, which determines the nature of the final product.

elements.content: All reagents were used without any further purification: 4,4′-bipyridyl (98%) and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (≥98%) were purchased from Aldrich; l-aspartic acid (≥98%, Fluka); zinc carbonate basic (BDH); and Na4iminodisuccinate (Baypure CX 100, Lanxess). The synthesis was carried out using Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves under autogenous pressure. The TGA data was recorded using a Seiko S-II instrument. X-ray powder diffraction data were collected with Cu Kα1 radiation on a Stoe Stadi-P diffractometer using a linear position sensitive detector. The CO2 sorption isotherm was measured using SCR grade high purity CO2 on a Hiden IGA gravimetric sorption balance at 198 K. Prior activation of samples was carried out at 120 °C overnight at 10−7 mbar.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

All reagents were used without any further purification: 4,4'-bipyridyl (98%) and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (≥98%) were purchased from Aldrich; l-aspartic acid (≥98%, Fluka); zinc carbonate basic (BDH); and Na4iminodisuccinate (Baypure CX 100, Lanxess). The synthesis was carried out using Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves under autogenous pressure. The TGA data was recorded using a Seiko S-II instrument. X-ray powder diffraction data were collected with Cu Kα1 radiation on a Stoe Stadi-P diffractometer using a linear position sensitive detector. The CO2 sorption isotherm was measured using SCR grade high purity CO2 on a Hiden IGA gravimetric sorption balance at 198 K. Prior activation of samples was carried out at 120 °C overnight at 10-7 mbar.

elements.content: Yellow crystals of 1 with pseudohexagonal external morphology were synthesized by stirring Zn carbonate basic (0.075 g, 0.219 mmol), l-aspartic acid (0.175 g, 1.32 mmol), and 4,4′-bipyridyl (0.103 g, 0.66 mmol) in a water/methanol mixture (2.65/1.35 mL, respectively), giving a molar composition for the reaction of 1:2:1 Zn/asp/bipy. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 23 mL autoclave and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. Upon cooling at a rate of 0.2 °C min−1 to room temperature, the product was filtered and washed with water and methanol. The pH before the reaction was 5.2, increasing to 7.2 after the reaction. Yield = 11.95% based on Zn2+. Elemental analysis (%): found (calc for Zn2(C8H7NO8)(C10H8N7)(H2O)3) C = 37.17 (37.05), H = 3.60 (3.63), N = 7.24 (7.21).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1, [Zn2(C8H7NO8)(C10H8N2)]⋅3H2O

Yellow crystals of 1 with pseudohexagonal external morphology were synthesized by stirring Zn carbonate basic (0.075 g, 0.219 mmol), l-aspartic acid (0.175 g, 1.32 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridyl (0.103 g, 0.66 mmol) in a water/methanol mixture (2.65/1.35 mL, respectively), giving a molar composition for the reaction of 1:2:1 Zn/asp/bipy. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 23 mL autoclave and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. Upon cooling at a rate of 0.2 °C min-1 to room temperature, the product was filtered and washed with water and methanol. The pH before the reaction was 5.2, increasing to 7.2 after the reaction. Yield = 11.95% based on Zn2+. Elemental analysis (%): found (calc for Zn2(C8H7NO8)(C10H8N7)(H2O)3) C = 37.17 (37.05), H = 3.60 (3.63), N = 7.24 (7.21).

elements.content: Optical and scanning electron microscopy and crystallography demonstrate that these crystals are extensively twinned, and the framework structure is globally disordered. Pseudohexagonal external morphology is observed, a result of cyclical twinning, with multiple twin boundaries intersecting at 180° or 60°. A few crystals appeared to be prismatic but with opposite faces not parallel to each other. This external form is not consistent with mmm or 2/m point symmetry and also indicated that these crystals are twinned.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structural Studies

Optical and scanning electron microscopy and crystallography demonstrate that these crystals are extensively twinned, and the framework structure is globally disordered. Pseudohexagonal external morphology is observed, a result of cyclical twinning, with multiple twin boundaries intersecting at 180° or 60°. A few crystals appeared to be prismatic but with opposite faces not parallel to each other. This external form is not consistent with mmm or 2/m point symmetry and also indicated that these crystals are twinned.

elements.content: X-ray data collection and analysis was performed on a crystal without obvious external features of twinning. X-ray intensity data were collected at the Daresbury Synchrotron Radiation Source, Station 9.8 MX, on a Bruker D8 diffractometer with an APEX II CCD detector with Si 111 monochromated radiation (λ = 0.671 Å). A small primitive unit cell with a = 5.0 Å could be identified from the strong reflections, while doubling a accounted for all the discrete reflections, including the weak reflections. The final cell constants obtained from least-squares refinement on 6188 reflections corresponded to a P212121 cell with the following dimensions: a = 10.0245(4) Å, b = 10.8912(4) Å, c = 20.7145(8) Å, and V = 2261.6(2) Å3. The frames were integrated with the Bruker SAINT v6.45a software package using a narrow-frame integration algorithm. The integration of the data using the orthorhombic unit cell yielded a total of 16980 reflections, of which 4083 were independent (completeness = 99.0%, R int = 5.93%). Analysis of the data showed negligible decay during data collection. The data were corrected for absorption, decay, and other errors using SADABS V2007-2. The structure was solved (by direct methods) and refined using SHELX. As all of the crystals were extensively twinned, the structure was solved by dividing the diffraction into two components, corresponding to two domains, which contributed 70% and 30%, respectively. However, within the structural model, the two domains are translated along the a-axis by 5 Å, and as Zn1 and Zn2 are separated by 5.14 Å along the same axis, there exists the possibility of mixing the two zinc atoms and their respectively bound O atoms (the closest separation between O atoms from the two components is only 0.5 Å). Therefore, it is hard to define which Zn and O atoms are bound together due to the overlapping of the two components, and the possibility of defining Zn−O bonds that are artificially shortened and lengthened exists (Figure ). Nevertheless, the connectivity is correct, but it is hard to define accurate bond distances and angles here. In addition, despite a significant amount of residual electron density from the structural model, it was not possible to locate any solvent molecules. All the representations and calculations performed on the crystal structure were realized from component 1, which corresponds to the domain that contributes to 70% of the observed diffraction.

X-ray intensity data were collected at the Daresbury Synchrotron Radiation Source, Station 9.8 MX, on a Bruker D8 diffractometer with an APEX II CCD detector with Si 111 monochromated radiation (λ = 0.671 Å). A small primitive unit cell with a = 5.0 Å could be identified from the strong reflections, while doubling a accounted for all the discrete reflections, including the weak reflections. The frames were integrated with the Bruker SAINT v6.45a software package using a narrow-frame integration algorithm. The integration of the data using the orthorhombic unit cell yielded a total of 16980 reflections, of which 4083 were independent (completeness = 99.0%, R int = 5.93%). Analysis of the data showed negligible decay during data collection. The data were corrected for absorption, decay, and other errors using SADABS V2007-2. However, within the structural model, the two domains are translated along the a-axis by 5 Å, and as Zn1 and Zn2 are separated by 5.14 Å along the same axis, there exists the possibility of mixing the two zinc atoms and their respectively bound O atoms (the closest separation between O atoms from the two components is only 0.5 Å). Nevertheless, the connectivity is correct, but it is hard to define accurate bond distances and angles here. In addition, despite a significant amount of residual electron density from the structural model, it was not possible to locate any solvent molecules. All the representations and calculations performed on the crystal structure were realized from component 1, which corresponds to the domain that contributes to 70% of the observed diffraction.

elements.content: Overlapping of the two components within the structure model of 1. The green moiety corresponds to component 1, which contributes to 70% of the observed diffraction. The blue moiety corresponds to component 2, which contributes to 30% of the observed diffraction.
elements.clean_text: 1  Overlapping of the two components within the structure model of 1. The green moiety corresponds to component 1, which contributes to 70% of the observed diffraction. The blue moiety corresponds to component 2, which contributes to 30% of the observed diffraction.

elements.content: The reaction of ZnCO3, l-aspartic acid (H2asp), and 4,4′-bipyridyl (bipy) in MeOH/H2O in a molar ratio of 1:2:1, respectively, under solvothermal conditions at 130 °C yielded yellow crystals. Structure solution and refinement revealed the framework composition to be [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)] (1), with transformation of the H2asp to meso-iminodisuccinic acid (H4IDS) (Figure ). The phase purity of the bulk sample was determined by powder X-ray diffraction and is consistent with the homogeneous morphology of the material under examination using scanning electron microscopy. Elemental analysis corresponds to the bulk composition [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)]·3H2O for 1 (elemental analysis (%) calculated: C 37.05, H 3.63, N 7.21; found: C 37.17, H 3.60, N 7.24) and is in good agreement with the crystallographically derived formula.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The reaction of ZnCO3, l-aspartic acid (H2asp), and 4,4'-bipyridyl (bipy) in MeOH/H2O in a molar ratio of 1:2:1, respectively, under solvothermal conditions at 130 °C yielded yellow crystals. Structure solution and refinement revealed the framework composition to be [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)] (1), with transformation of the H2asp to meso-iminodisuccinic acid (H4IDS) (Figure ). The phase purity of the bulk sample was determined by powder X-ray diffraction and is consistent with the homogeneous morphology of the material under examination using scanning electron microscopy. Elemental analysis corresponds to the bulk composition [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)]⋅3H2O for 1 (elemental analysis (%) calculated: C 37.05, H 3.63, N 7.21; found: C 37.17, H 3.60, N 7.24) and is in good agreement with the crystallographically derived formula.

elements.content: Conversion of aspartic acid to meso-iminodisuccinic acid.
elements.clean_text: 2  Conversion of aspartic acid to meso-iminodisuccinic acid.

elements.content: Careful control of the ratio of methanol to water molecules is required to form a single phase material, and any deviation from the 2:3 volumetric ratio described above results in the production of an additional gel phase, which could not be characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). Precise control of the reagent ratios was also found to be critical in forming a single phase material; the molar ratio of Zn/asp/bipy required to form [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)] is 1:2:1, whereas the expected molar ratio is 2:2:1, as two l-aspH2 molecules are needed to form H4IDS. The cooling rate was not found to be a critical factor in control of crystallizing the framework, suggesting that nucleation occurs during the dwelling stage at 130 °C. Increasing or decreasing the reaction time away from 72 h yielded an additional amorphous phase, which could not be indexed by PXRD. At temperatures below 130 °C and above 140 °C, all products are amorphous by PXRD, and at temperatures below 120 °C, no solid is formed. It is also possible to synthesize a largely amorphous material with some crystalline features using Na4IDS in an analogous preparation with zinc nitrate. The resulting PXRD pattern can be indexed to the same cell as 1, with the intense peaks of the 002, 012, 111, 020, 021, and 211 reflections particularly.
elements.clean_text: Careful control of the ratio of methanol to water molecules is required to form a single phase material, and any deviation from the 2:3 volumetric ratio described above results in the production of an additional gel phase, which could not be characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). Precise control of the reagent ratios was also found to be critical in forming a single phase material; the molar ratio of Zn/asp/bipy required to form [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)] is 1:2:1, whereas the expected molar ratio is 2:2:1, as two l-aspH2 molecules are needed to form H4IDS. The cooling rate was not found to be a critical factor in control of crystallizing the framework, suggesting that nucleation occurs during the dwelling stage at 130 °C. Increasing or decreasing the reaction time away from 72 h yielded an additional amorphous phase, which could not be indexed by PXRD. At temperatures below 130 °C and above 140 °C, all products are amorphous by PXRD, and at temperatures below 120 °C, no solid is formed. It is also possible to synthesize a largely amorphous material with some crystalline features using Na4IDS in an analogous preparation with zinc nitrate. The resulting PXRD pattern can be indexed to the same cell as 1, with the intense peaks of the 002, 012, 111, 020, 021, and 211 reflections particularly.

elements.content: Within 1, the IDS ligand binds to five separate Zn cations, which are present as two crystallographically independent Zn(II) centers (Zn1 and Zn2), which are six- and five-coordinate, respectively (Figure a). The IDS ligand displays three distinct coordination modes: (i) a central Zn1 ion is bound to two oxygen atoms and a nitrogen atom in an eight-membered O−N−O tridentate mer chelation which involves monodentate binding by two of the four carboxylate groups and the single amino group of the IDS ligand; (ii) the remaining oxygen atoms of the two carboxylate groups from the O−N−O chelation in mode i bridge to two Zn2 centers; and (iii) the two remaining carboxylate groups chelate to the two crystallographically distinct Zn centers. This is in contrast to the known molecular structures of IDS complexes, where the ligands are typically tetradentate, forming a 6-membered and two 5-membered metallocycles, from a central nitrogen (Figure b). However, an extended framework based upon IDS and zinc has been recently reported by Feller et al. with the formula [Zn2(IDS)], in which the tetra-acid was formed by analogous in-situ dimerization during solvothermal synthesis with l-aspH2 and Zn(II) acetate. This was suggested to occur via formation of a butenedioic acid intermediate, followed by Michael addition of H2asp across the alkene. Unlike 1, the formed framework [Zn2(IDS)] is two-dimensional but displays some similar structural characteristics to 1. There are two independent Zn centers, and [Zn2(IDS)] displays two IDS coordination modes, which are also observed in 1: the eight-membered O−N−O tridentate mer chelation to Zn and the bridging functionality of the chelating carboxylate groups. However, the key difference between the two compounds can be noted from the binding modes of the two carboxylate groups, which are not involved in the central chelation. Within [Zn2(IDS)], these groups each coordinate to two Zn(II) ions (a total of four Zn), whereas in 1 they are bound to one each (a total of two Zn) (Figure c). The absence of these binding modes within 1 increases the dimensionality of the framework, from 2D to 3D, and decreases the denticity of the ligand, from hepta- to pentadentate, because bipy occupies the remaining Zn coordination sites and connects the layers.

The IDS ligand displays three distinct coordination modes: (i) a central Zn1 ion is bound to two oxygen atoms and a nitrogen atom in an eight-membered O-N-O tridentate mer chelation which involves monodentate binding by two of the four carboxylate groups and the single amino group of the IDS ligand; (ii) the remaining oxygen atoms of the two carboxylate groups from the O-N-O chelation in mode i bridge to two Zn2 centers; and (iii) the two remaining carboxylate groups chelate to the two crystallographically distinct Zn centers. This is in contrast to the known molecular structures of IDS complexes, where the ligands are typically tetradentate, forming a 6-membered and two 5-membered metallocycles, from a central nitrogen (Figure b). However, an extended framework based upon IDS and zinc has been recently reported by Feller et al. with the formula [Zn2(IDS)], in which the tetra-acid was formed by analogous in-situ dimerization during solvothermal synthesis with l-aspH2 and Zn(II) acetate. This was suggested to occur via formation of a butenedioic acid intermediate, followed by Michael addition of H2asp across the alkene. Unlike 1, the formed framework [Zn2(IDS)] is two-dimensional but displays some similar structural characteristics to 1. There are two independent Zn centers, and [Zn2(IDS)] displays two IDS coordination modes, which are also observed in 1: the eight-membered O-N-O tridentate mer chelation to Zn and the bridging functionality of the chelating carboxylate groups. However, the key difference between the two compounds can be noted from the binding modes of the two carboxylate groups, which are not involved in the central chelation. Within [Zn2(IDS)], these groups each coordinate to two Zn(II) ions (a total of four Zn), whereas in 1 they are bound to one each (a total of two Zn) (Figure c). The absence of these binding modes within 1 increases the dimensionality of the framework, from 2D to 3D, and decreases the denticity of the ligand, from hepta- to pentadentate, because bipy occupies the remaining Zn coordination sites and connects the layers.

elements.content: (a) The three coordination modes of the IDS ligand within [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)]·3H2O (1). The eight-membered O1−N1−O3 tridentate mer chelation to Zn1, the single oxygen binding to Zn2 (O2−Zn2 and O4−Zn2), and the bidentate chelation of the carboxylate moieties to the crystallographically unique Zn centers (O5−Zn2−O6 and O7−Zn1−O8). (b) Coordination modes of the IDS ligand within [Zn2(IDS)]. The two analogous IDS binding modes to zinc are evident: the eight-membered O2−N1−O6 tridentate mer chelation to Zn1, and the single oxygen binding to Zn2 (O1−Zn2 and O5−Zn2). The remaining three coordination modes are also evident: the single binding of an oxygen to Zn (O4−Zn2 and O3−Zn1), bidentate coordination of a μ1 and a μ2 oxygen to Zn (O7−Zn2−O8), and, finally, the single oxygen binding from a μ2 oxygen (O7−Zn1). Carbon is gray, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, zinc1 is cyan, and zinc2 is yellow. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) The three coordination modes of the IDS ligand within [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)]⋅3H2O (1). The eight-membered O1-N1-O3 tridentate mer chelation to Zn1, the single oxygen binding to Zn2 (O2-Zn2 and O4-Zn2), and the bidentate chelation of the carboxylate moieties to the crystallographically unique Zn centers (O5-Zn2-O6 and O7-Zn1-O8). (b) Coordination modes of the IDS ligand within [Zn2(IDS)]. The two analogous IDS binding modes to zinc are evident: the eight-membered O2-N1-O6 tridentate mer chelation to Zn1, and the single oxygen binding to Zn2 (O1-Zn2 and O5-Zn2). The remaining three coordination modes are also evident: the single binding of an oxygen to Zn (O4-Zn2 and O3-Zn1), bidentate coordination of a μ1 and a μ2 oxygen to Zn (O7-Zn2-O8), and, finally, the single oxygen binding from a μ2 oxygen (O7-Zn1). Carbon is gray, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, zinc1 is cyan, and zinc2 is yellow. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The two independent Zn atoms in the asymmetric unit of 1 are in irregular coordination environments. This is well-documented for zinc complexes, which adopt coordination environments that are heavily distorted away from the classical polyhedron geometries without any significant energy penalty. Zn1 is six-coordinate (Figure a), bonding to two IDS ligands and a single pyridyl from bipy. One IDS ligand binds to Zn1 via the O−N−O tridentate chelation described above. The coordination sphere is completed by the bidentate chelation from oxygen atoms of a carboxylate moiety of a neighboring IDS ligand and finally by coordination of a single nitrogen atom from bipy. This gives a Zn1 bond valence of 2.19. The bidentate coordination of the carboxylate group is distinctly asymmetrical, with a long Zn−O carboxylate bond (2.67 Å), which is partly compensated by formation of an intramolecular CO···HN hydrogen bond (2.31 Å) between the carboxylate group and the amine group within IDS. Zn2 is five-coordinate (Figure b), with four carboxylate oxygen donors arising from coordination from three distinct IDS ligands and one nitrogen atom from bipy, forming a highly distorted square based pyramid, with a total bond valence of 1.94. Again, the bidentate carboxylate chelation is distinctly asymmetrical (there is one short Zn−O bond, 2.00 Å, and one long bond, 2.48 Å), with the weaker coordinating oxygen accepting an aromatic CH···OC intermolecular hydrogen bond from a neighboring bipy ligand (2.51 Å). The bond valence sums at both Zn sites indicate a chemically correct description of the bonding has been deduced, despite the existence of two disordered components within the diffraction data.
elements.clean_text: The two independent Zn atoms in the asymmetric unit of 1 are in irregular coordination environments. This is well-documented for zinc complexes, which adopt coordination environments that are heavily distorted away from the classical polyhedron geometries without any significant energy penalty. Zn1 is six-coordinate (Figure a), bonding to two IDS ligands and a single pyridyl from bipy. One IDS ligand binds to Zn1 via the O-N-O tridentate chelation described above. The coordination sphere is completed by the bidentate chelation from oxygen atoms of a carboxylate moiety of a neighboring IDS ligand and finally by coordination of a single nitrogen atom from bipy. This gives a Zn1 bond valence of 2.19. The bidentate coordination of the carboxylate group is distinctly asymmetrical, with a long Zn-O carboxylate bond (2.67 Å), which is partly compensated by formation of an intramolecular CO⋅⋅⋅HN hydrogen bond (2.31 Å) between the carboxylate group and the amine group within IDS. Zn2 is five-coordinate (Figure b), with four carboxylate oxygen donors arising from coordination from three distinct IDS ligands and one nitrogen atom from bipy, forming a highly distorted square based pyramid, with a total bond valence of 1.94. Again, the bidentate carboxylate chelation is distinctly asymmetrical (there is one short Zn-O bond, 2.00 Å, and one long bond, 2.48 Å), with the weaker coordinating oxygen accepting an aromatic CH⋅⋅⋅OC intermolecular hydrogen bond from a neighboring bipy ligand (2.51 Å). The bond valence sums at both Zn sites indicate a chemically correct description of the bonding has been deduced, despite the existence of two disordered components within the diffraction data.

elements.content: (a) Distorted octahedral coordination environment of Zn1. The metal center is bound to two IDS ligands and a single bipy ligand. The longer Zn−O distance of the more weakly coordinating oxygen (O7) of the unsymmetrical bidentate carboxylate group is compensated by a CO···HN intramolecular hydrogen bond of the amine group in IDS, shown by a broken yellow line. (b) Distorted square-bipyramidal coordination environment of Zn2, where the metal center is bound to three IDS ligands and a single bipy ligand. The weaker coordinating oxygen (O5) of the carboxylate group is compensated by a CH···OC hydrogen bond from a neighboring bipyridyl ligand, as shown by a broken yellow line. Carbon is gray, hydrogen is white, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, zinc1 is cyan, and zinc2 is yellow.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Distorted octahedral coordination environment of Zn1. The metal center is bound to two IDS ligands and a single bipy ligand. The longer Zn-O distance of the more weakly coordinating oxygen (O7) of the unsymmetrical bidentate carboxylate group is compensated by a CO⋅⋅⋅HN intramolecular hydrogen bond of the amine group in IDS, shown by a broken yellow line. (b) Distorted square-bipyramidal coordination environment of Zn2, where the metal center is bound to three IDS ligands and a single bipy ligand. The weaker coordinating oxygen (O5) of the carboxylate group is compensated by a CH⋅⋅⋅OC hydrogen bond from a neighboring bipyridyl ligand, as shown by a broken yellow line. Carbon is gray, hydrogen is white, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, zinc1 is cyan, and zinc2 is yellow.

elements.content: The two carboxylate groups involved in the O−N−O chelation of a Zn1 bridge to Zn2, as described above. This bonding occurs along the a-axis and leads to the formation of an infinite chain of alternating Zn1 and Zn2 atoms linked by carboxylate groups. These chains are linked together by two carboxylate terminated arms of IDS in the b direction, with one carboxylate binding to Zn1 and the other binding to Zn2, forming a 2D layer (Figure a). Viewing the two-dimensional layer along the a-axis (orthogonal to the plane of layer formation) demonstrates it takes a corrugated shape (Figure b). This shape is due to the arclike conformation of the IDS ligand within the structure and a 180° rotation of the IDS ligand at each Zn connection along the b-axis. The arclike conformation of the ligand arises from the flexible −CH2− carbons (C5 and C7) in the carboxylate arms that point along the b-axis, leading to an angle of 100° between the chains of alternating Zn1 and Zn2 atoms with respect to the ligand. In order to accommodate the bipy ligand, the IDS ligands coordinate trans to each other, rotating by 180° and leading to the corrugated shape of the two-dimensional layer. The bipy ligand links the layers in the c direction through bonding between Zn1 and Zn2, at an angle of 44.8° from the plane of the layer (Figure c). Each successive layer is rotated by 180° about c in order to accommodate coordination to the bipy nitrogen, leading to the formation of an ABA stacking pattern along c (Figure d).
elements.clean_text: The two carboxylate groups involved in the O-N-O chelation of a Zn1 bridge to Zn2, as described above. This bonding occurs along the a-axis and leads to the formation of an infinite chain of alternating Zn1 and Zn2 atoms linked by carboxylate groups. These chains are linked together by two carboxylate terminated arms of IDS in the b direction, with one carboxylate binding to Zn1 and the other binding to Zn2, forming a 2D layer (Figure a). Viewing the two-dimensional layer along the a-axis (orthogonal to the plane of layer formation) demonstrates it takes a corrugated shape (Figure b). This shape is due to the arclike conformation of the IDS ligand within the structure and a 180° rotation of the IDS ligand at each Zn connection along the b-axis. The arclike conformation of the ligand arises from the flexible -CH2- carbons (C5 and C7) in the carboxylate arms that point along the b-axis, leading to an angle of 100° between the chains of alternating Zn1 and Zn2 atoms with respect to the ligand. In order to accommodate the bipy ligand, the IDS ligands coordinate trans to each other, rotating by 180° and leading to the corrugated shape of the two-dimensional layer. The bipy ligand links the layers in the c direction through bonding between Zn1 and Zn2, at an angle of 44.8° from the plane of the layer (Figure c). Each successive layer is rotated by 180° about c in order to accommodate coordination to the bipy nitrogen, leading to the formation of an ABA stacking pattern along c (Figure d).

elements.content: (a) 2D layer of Zn with IDS in the ab plane. The layer is comprised of alternating Zn atoms along the a-axis linked via the tridentate chelation and the bridging functionality of the carboxylate groups. The layer is completed by the remaining two carboxylate groups, which bridge to an adjacent chain of Zn atoms. (b) (i) The layer rotated by 90°, viewed down the a-axis, demonstrating the corrugated shape. The red atoms/bonds highlight a single IDS ligand. (ii) The arc shape of the ligand, with the angle between the Zn atoms with respect to the center of the ligand equal to 100°. (c) The bipy ligand is at an angle of 44.8° with respect to the layer comprised of Zn and IDS along the b-axis. Each successive layer of Zn and IDS along the c-axis is rotated by 180° with each bipy connection, leading to (d) an ABA stacking pattern. Carbon is gray, hydrogen is white, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, zinc1 is cyan, and zinc2 is yellow.

(ii) The arc shape of the ligand, with the angle between the Zn atoms with respect to the center of the ligand equal to 100°. (c) The bipy ligand is at an angle of 44.8° with respect to the layer comprised of Zn and IDS along the b-axis. Each successive layer of Zn and IDS along the c-axis is rotated by 180° with each bipy connection, leading to (d) an ABA stacking pattern. Carbon is gray, hydrogen is white, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, zinc1 is cyan, and zinc2 is yellow.

elements.content: Topological analysis of the framework is best performed by first assigning the 2D layer of Zn with IDS described above (Figure a) and adding the straight bipy edge to yield the final network assignment of the formed 3D net. By assigning the Zn atoms as nodes and the covalent connections made between them by IDS as edges (Figure a and b), the resulting layer takes the form of the 36 hexagonal lattice hxl (Figure c), which is 6-connected and uninodal, despite the two geometrically distinct Zn atoms within the crystal structure of 1. Addition of the bipy edge to the layer leads to the 7-connected net ose (Figure d), as defined by the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource. The net is denoted by the Schläfli symbol 36.48.57, of which there are no other known examples of coordinatively or covalently bound frameworks. The network topology was determined using TOPOS 4.0 Professional.
elements.clean_text: Topological analysis of the framework is best performed by first assigning the 2D layer of Zn with IDS described above (Figure a) and adding the straight bipy edge to yield the final network assignment of the formed 3D net. By assigning the Zn atoms as nodes and the covalent connections made between them by IDS as edges (Figure a and b), the resulting layer takes the form of the 36 hexagonal lattice hxl (Figure c), which is 6-connected and uninodal, despite the two geometrically distinct Zn atoms within the crystal structure of 1. Addition of the bipy edge to the layer leads to the 7-connected net ose (Figure d), as defined by the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource. The net is denoted by the Schläfli symbol 36.48.57, of which there are no other known examples of coordinatively or covalently bound frameworks. The network topology was determined using TOPOS 4.0 Professional.

elements.content: Network assignment of [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)], assigning the Zn atoms as the nodes and the IDS and the bipy linkages as edges. (a) The topological edges (orange) are overlaid upon the 2D layer outlined in Figure , leading to (b) the uninodal 36 layer designated hxl. The black atoms correspond to the Zn nodes. (c) Addition of the bipy edge in the structure leads to the network assignment of the 7-connected net ose.
elements.clean_text: 6  Network assignment of [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)], assigning the Zn atoms as the nodes and the IDS and the bipy linkages as edges. (a) The topological edges (orange) are overlaid upon the 2D layer outlined in Figure , leading to (b) the uninodal 36 layer designated hxl. The black atoms correspond to the Zn nodes. (c) Addition of the bipy edge in the structure leads to the network assignment of the 7-connected net ose.

elements.content: The porosity arises in 1 from the open space in the crystal structure between the 2D layers of Zn and IDS, which are pillared by bipy. This is demonstrated by the Connolly surface, where the pore surface is lined by two bipy molecules and two IDS ligands from two opposite layers, leading to one-dimensional channels along the crystallographic a-axis that have approximately oval-shaped windows with a cross-section of 4 × 3 Å2 (Figure ). These lead to larger cavities, which have a cross section of 6 × 6 Å2. The distance between the window opening and the center of the cavity is 2.5 Å, which corresponds to one fourth of the cell length of the a-axis. Each cavity is slightly offset from the center of the channel along b, due to the alternating Zn1 and Zn2 atoms along a and their respective coordination environments. The Zn1 atom is surrounded by a bulky tridentate O−N−O chelation, which protrudes into the channels, taking up more room than Zn2, which is linked by oxygen atoms from IDS carboxylate groups. The cavity displacement along b causes the channels to adopt a sinusoidal shape. The environments of the cavity and the window are very similar, as the atom types and functional groups which line the window center are the same as those which line the cavity (measured by inserting a fictitious “void” atom in the center of the cavity/window and crystallographically measuring the framework atoms which are closest to the “void”) (Figure ). In both cases, the closest atoms are oxygen and hydrogen, creating a hydrophilic environment, which is ideally suited to the guest water molecules, as defined by the elemental and thermogravimetric analysis.

In both cases, the closest atoms are oxygen and hydrogen, creating a hydrophilic environment, which is ideally suited to the guest water molecules, as defined by the elemental and thermogravimetric analysis.

elements.content: View of the Connolly surface of the channels along the [100] axis of 1 (top) and perpendicular to the [010] axis (bottom). The black spaces are open gaps within the structure. The framework atoms are shown in the space-filling style, and the calculated surface is highlighted in blue. The cavity and window are labeled in white. Carbon is gray, hydrogen is white, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, and zinc is purple.

elements.content: “Void” atom, with the closest contacts to the framework highlighted by green bonds in the pore window, which has a cross section of 4 × 3 Å2 (left), and “void” atom cavity, with the closest contacts to the framework highlighted again by green bonds. The fictitious “void” atom is labeled green. All other atoms are labeled according to the color scheme in Figure a.

elements.content: Framework 1 has 240 Å3 solvent accessible volume, which is equivalent to 11% of the total volume of the unit cell, as determined by PLATON. As noted by the elemental analysis, within the as-prepared material, the channels contain three water molecules per formula unit, which have a combined volume of 59.1 Å3. As Z (the number of asymmetric units per unit cell) is equal to 4, the pore volume occupied by water molecules equates to 236.4 Å3, demonstrating that the pores are 99% filled. Thermogravimetric analysis of 1 under a dynamic nitrogen flow reveals a weight loss of 8.82% between room temperature and 150 °C, which is attributed to the removal of the three water molecules within the pores (calculated weight loss 9.22% from the analyzed composition), followed by a plateau and a mass loss of 63.41% at 320 °C, which is attributed to the breakdown of the framework (calculated weight loss 63.02% from the analyzed composition) (Figure a). The similarity of the PXRD patterns of the as-prepared and the post-TGA material demonstrates that framework 1 is stable to guest loss, with the full width at half-maximum (fwhm) of the 002 peak being 0.15° in the as-prepared material and 0.17° in the post-TGA material (Figure b). Further evidence of the stability of the structure is provided by the elemental analysis of the desolvated material, which corresponds to the composition of 1 without any guest molecules, [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)] (elemental analysis (%) calculated: C 40.84, H 2.86, N 7.94; found: C 41.01, H 2.79, N 8.23).

As Z (the number of asymmetric units per unit cell) is equal to 4, the pore volume occupied by water molecules equates to 236.4 Å3, demonstrating that the pores are 99% filled. Thermogravimetric analysis of 1 under a dynamic nitrogen flow reveals a weight loss of 8.82% between room temperature and 150 °C, which is attributed to the removal of the three water molecules within the pores (calculated weight loss 9.22% from the analyzed composition), followed by a plateau and a mass loss of 63.41% at 320 °C, which is attributed to the breakdown of the framework (calculated weight loss 63.02% from the analyzed composition) (Figure a). The similarity of the PXRD patterns of the as-prepared and the post-TGA material demonstrates that framework 1 is stable to guest loss, with the full width at half-maximum (fwhm) of the 002 peak being 0.15° in the as-prepared material and 0.17° in the post-TGA material (Figure b). Further evidence of the stability of the structure is provided by the elemental analysis of the desolvated material, which corresponds to the composition of 1 without any guest molecules, [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)] (elemental analysis (%) calculated: C 40.84, H 2.86, N 7.94; found: C 41.01, H 2.79, N 8.23).

elements.content: (a) TGA data for 1 measured in an N2 atmosphere. The weight loss of 8.82% between room temperature and 150 °C is attributed to the loss of the three water molecules which occupy the channels of 1. (b) PXRD pattern of 1 as-synthesized and after the guest water molecules have been removed by heating to 150 °C.

(b) PXRD pattern of 1 as-synthesized and after the guest water molecules have been removed by heating to 150 °C.

elements.content: The permanent porosity of 1 is demonstrated by a CO2 sorption isotherm measured at 195 K, in which typical type I behavior for a microporous material is observed (Figure ). The isotherm also showed that the mass uptake of CO2 at saturation was 12%, and the BET derived surface area is 183(7) m2 g−1 (determined from 26 data points in the range P/P 0 = 0.01−0.27). The observed hysteresis upon desorption of CO2 from the framework arises from the slow adsorption kinetics at 195 K (>60 min per data point, saturation time approximately 12 h), rather than specific structural change, as there was no evidence for structural change from PXRD. The final isotherm point upon desorption does not return to zero uptake due to temperature instabilities at very low relative pressures resulting from the prohibitively slow kinetics. The material was found to be nonporous to N2, behavior which is not uncommon in MOFs prepared with 4,4′-bipyridyl with pore sizes of the scale of 1.

The final isotherm point upon desorption does not return to zero uptake due to temperature instabilities at very low relative pressures resulting from the prohibitively slow kinetics. The material was found to be nonporous to N2, behavior which is not uncommon in MOFs prepared with 4,4'-bipyridyl with pore sizes of the scale of 1.

elements.content: Adsorption isotherm of 1 measured at 195 K. The saturation of CO2 corresponds to a mass uptake of 12%, and the BET surface area was determined to be 183(7) m2 g−1.

elements.content: In summary, we report that the combination of Zn(II), aspartic acid, and bipy under solvothermal conditions promotes the in-situ ligand transformation with the coupling of two aspartic acid molecules to generate the tetracarboxylic acid iminodisuccinic acid. The thus formed IDS ligand is captured via metal coordination in a framework with a bipy co-ligand, generating the new porous three-dimensional [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)] framework. The process is unique to Zn(II), not observed in analogous reactions with divalent cobalt, nickel, or copper by powder X-ray diffraction. This is surprising, as the [M(asp)(H2O)2]·H2O divalent salts are formed for all three metals. This may be due to the greater Lewis acidity of Zn(II), allowing conversion of aspartic acid to iminodisuccinic acid and the ability of Zn(II) to adopt distorted coordination geometries, a requirement for the formation of this framework. The structure was solved from a crystal which displayed a combination of twinning and disorder. This work highlights the crucial role rigid organic pillars play in generating porosity in metal−amino acid derived extended structures, as they prevent complete filling of the available space by the highly flexible amino acid linkers.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we report that the combination of Zn(II), aspartic acid, and bipy under solvothermal conditions promotes the in-situ ligand transformation with the coupling of two aspartic acid molecules to generate the tetracarboxylic acid iminodisuccinic acid. The thus formed IDS ligand is captured via metal coordination in a framework with a bipy co-ligand, generating the new porous three-dimensional [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)] framework. The process is unique to Zn(II), not observed in analogous reactions with divalent cobalt, nickel, or copper by powder X-ray diffraction. This is surprising, as the [M(asp)(H2O)2]⋅H2O divalent salts are formed for all three metals. This may be due to the greater Lewis acidity of Zn(II), allowing conversion of aspartic acid to iminodisuccinic acid and the ability of Zn(II) to adopt distorted coordination geometries, a requirement for the formation of this framework. The structure was solved from a crystal which displayed a combination of twinning and disorder. This work highlights the crucial role rigid organic pillars play in generating porosity in metal-amino acid derived extended structures, as they prevent complete filling of the available space by the highly flexible amino acid linkers.

Diagrammatical representation of the selection of the vertices within the 2D layer of 1. Description of the diffraction data from 1 and its analysis. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

Solvothermal conditions can lead to chemical transformations involving the functional groups of amino acids. For a review of the variety of functional group transformations, see:

Connolly surfaces of 1 were generated using Accelrys Materials Studio 4.0. In all cases, a Connolly probe radius of 1.0 Å was used.

The sample was desolvated by heating in a Schlenk tube overnight en vacuo at 100 °C.

cln_elements.content: Yellow crystals of 1 with pseudohexagonal external morphology were synthesized by stirring Zn carbonate basic (0.075 g, 0.219 mmol), l-aspartic acid (0.175 g, 1.32 mmol), and 4,4′-bipyridyl (0.103 g, 0.66 mmol) in a water/methanol mixture (2.65/1.35 mL, respectively), giving a molar composition for the reaction of 1:2:1 Zn/asp/bipy. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 23 mL autoclave and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. Upon cooling at a rate of 0.2 °C min−1 to room temperature, the product was filtered and washed with water and methanol. The pH before the reaction was 5.2, increasing to 7.2 after the reaction. Yield = 11.95% based on Zn2+. Elemental analysis (%): found (calc for Zn2(C8H7NO8)(C10H8N7)(H2O)3) C = 37.17 (37.05), H = 3.60 (3.63), N = 7.24 (7.21).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1, [Zn2(C8H7NO8)(C10H8N2)]⋅3H2O

Yellow crystals of 1 with pseudohexagonal external morphology were synthesized by stirring Zn carbonate basic (0.075 g, 0.219 mmol), l-aspartic acid (0.175 g, 1.32 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridyl (0.103 g, 0.66 mmol) in a water/methanol mixture (2.65/1.35 mL, respectively), giving a molar composition for the reaction of 1:2:1 Zn/asp/bipy. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 23 mL autoclave and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. Upon cooling at a rate of 0.2 °C min-1 to room temperature, the product was filtered and washed with water and methanol. The pH before the reaction was 5.2, increasing to 7.2 after the reaction. Yield = 11.95% based on Zn2+. Elemental analysis (%): found (calc for Zn2(C8H7NO8)(C10H8N7)(H2O)3) C = 37.17 (37.05), H = 3.60 (3.63), N = 7.24 (7.21).

cln_elements.content:
Framework 1 has 240 Å3 solvent accessible volume, which is equivalent to 11% of the total volume of the unit cell, as determined by PLATON. As noted by the elemental analysis, within the as-prepared material, the channels contain three water molecules per formula unit, which have a combined volume of 59.1 Å3. As Z (the number of asymmetric units per unit cell) is equal to 4, the pore volume occupied by water molecules equates to 236.4 Å3, demonstrating that the pores are 99% filled. Thermogravimetric analysis of 1 under a dynamic nitrogen flow reveals a weight loss of 8.82% between room temperature and 150 °C, which is attributed to the removal of the three water molecules within the pores (calculated weight loss 9.22% from the analyzed composition), followed by a plateau and a mass loss of 63.41% at 320 °C, which is attributed to the breakdown of the framework (calculated weight loss 63.02% from the analyzed composition) (Figure a). The similarity of the PXRD patterns of the as-prepared and the post-TGA material demonstrates that framework 1 is stable to guest loss, with the full width at half-maximum (fwhm) of the 002 peak being 0.15° in the as-prepared material and 0.17° in the post-TGA material (Figure b). Further evidence of the stability of the structure is provided by the elemental analysis of the desolvated material, which corresponds to the composition of 1 without any guest molecules, [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)] (elemental analysis (%) calculated: C 40.84, H 2.86, N 7.94; found: C 41.01, H 2.79, N 8.23).

The permanent porosity of 1 is demonstrated by a CO2 sorption isotherm measured at 195 K, in which typical type I behavior for a microporous material is observed (Figure ). The isotherm also showed that the mass uptake of CO2 at saturation was 12%, and the BET derived surface area is 183(7) m2 g−1 (determined from 26 data points in the range P/P 0 = 0.01−0.27). The observed hysteresis upon desorption of CO2 from the framework arises from the slow adsorption kinetics at 195 K (>60 min per data point, saturation time approximately 12 h), rather than specific structural change, as there was no evidence for structural change from PXRD. The final isotherm point upon desorption does not return to zero uptake due to temperature instabilities at very low relative pressures resulting from the prohibitively slow kinetics. The material was found to be nonporous to N2, behavior which is not uncommon in MOFs prepared with 4,4′-bipyridyl with pore sizes of the scale of 1.

cln_elements.content: Overlapping of the two components within the structure model of 1. The green moiety corresponds to component 1, which contributes to 70% of the observed diffraction. The blue moiety corresponds to component 2, which contributes to 30% of the observed diffraction.

cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Conversion of aspartic acid to meso-iminodisuccinic acid.

cln_elements.content: (a) The three coordination modes of the IDS ligand within [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)]·3H2O (1). The eight-membered O1−N1−O3 tridentate mer chelation to Zn1, the single oxygen binding to Zn2 (O2−Zn2 and O4−Zn2), and the bidentate chelation of the carboxylate moieties to the crystallographically unique Zn centers (O5−Zn2−O6 and O7−Zn1−O8). (b) Coordination modes of the IDS ligand within [Zn2(IDS)]. The two analogous IDS binding modes to zinc are evident: the eight-membered O2−N1−O6 tridentate mer chelation to Zn1, and the single oxygen binding to Zn2 (O1−Zn2 and O5−Zn2). The remaining three coordination modes are also evident: the single binding of an oxygen to Zn (O4−Zn2 and O3−Zn1), bidentate coordination of a μ1 and a μ2 oxygen to Zn (O7−Zn2−O8), and, finally, the single oxygen binding from a μ2 oxygen (O7−Zn1). Carbon is gray, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, zinc1 is cyan, and zinc2 is yellow. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) The three coordination modes of the IDS ligand within [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)]⋅3H2O (1). The eight-membered O1-N1-O3 tridentate mer chelation to Zn1, the single oxygen binding to Zn2 (O2-Zn2 and O4-Zn2), and the bidentate chelation of the carboxylate moieties to the crystallographically unique Zn centers (O5-Zn2-O6 and O7-Zn1-O8). (b) Coordination modes of the IDS ligand within [Zn2(IDS)]. The two analogous IDS binding modes to zinc are evident: the eight-membered O2-N1-O6 tridentate mer chelation to Zn1, and the single oxygen binding to Zn2 (O1-Zn2 and O5-Zn2). The remaining three coordination modes are also evident: the single binding of an oxygen to Zn (O4-Zn2 and O3-Zn1), bidentate coordination of a μ1 and a μ2 oxygen to Zn (O7-Zn2-O8), and, finally, the single oxygen binding from a μ2 oxygen (O7-Zn1). Carbon is gray, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, zinc1 is cyan, and zinc2 is yellow. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: (a) Distorted octahedral coordination environment of Zn1. The metal center is bound to two IDS ligands and a single bipy ligand. The longer Zn−O distance of the more weakly coordinating oxygen (O7) of the unsymmetrical bidentate carboxylate group is compensated by a CO···HN intramolecular hydrogen bond of the amine group in IDS, shown by a broken yellow line. (b) Distorted square-bipyramidal coordination environment of Zn2, where the metal center is bound to three IDS ligands and a single bipy ligand. The weaker coordinating oxygen (O5) of the carboxylate group is compensated by a CH···OC hydrogen bond from a neighboring bipyridyl ligand, as shown by a broken yellow line. Carbon is gray, hydrogen is white, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, zinc1 is cyan, and zinc2 is yellow.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Distorted octahedral coordination environment of Zn1. The metal center is bound to two IDS ligands and a single bipy ligand. The longer Zn-O distance of the more weakly coordinating oxygen (O7) of the unsymmetrical bidentate carboxylate group is compensated by a CO⋅⋅⋅HN intramolecular hydrogen bond of the amine group in IDS, shown by a broken yellow line. (b) Distorted square-bipyramidal coordination environment of Zn2, where the metal center is bound to three IDS ligands and a single bipy ligand. The weaker coordinating oxygen (O5) of the carboxylate group is compensated by a CH⋅⋅⋅OC hydrogen bond from a neighboring bipyridyl ligand, as shown by a broken yellow line. Carbon is gray, hydrogen is white, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, zinc1 is cyan, and zinc2 is yellow.

cln_elements.content: (a) 2D layer of Zn with IDS in the ab plane. The layer is comprised of alternating Zn atoms along the a-axis linked via the tridentate chelation and the bridging functionality of the carboxylate groups. The layer is completed by the remaining two carboxylate groups, which bridge to an adjacent chain of Zn atoms. (b) (i) The layer rotated by 90°, viewed down the a-axis, demonstrating the corrugated shape. The red atoms/bonds highlight a single IDS ligand. (ii) The arc shape of the ligand, with the angle between the Zn atoms with respect to the center of the ligand equal to 100°. (c) The bipy ligand is at an angle of 44.8° with respect to the layer comprised of Zn and IDS along the b-axis. Each successive layer of Zn and IDS along the c-axis is rotated by 180° with each bipy connection, leading to (d) an ABA stacking pattern. Carbon is gray, hydrogen is white, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, zinc1 is cyan, and zinc2 is yellow.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  (a) 2D layer of Zn with IDS in the ab plane. The layer is comprised of alternating Zn atoms along the a-axis linked via the tridentate chelation and the bridging functionality of the carboxylate groups. The layer is completed by the remaining two carboxylate groups, which bridge to an adjacent chain of Zn atoms. (b) (i) The layer rotated by 90°, viewed down the a-axis, demonstrating the corrugated shape. The red atoms/bonds highlight a single IDS ligand. (ii) The arc shape of the ligand, with the angle between the Zn atoms with respect to the center of the ligand equal to 100°. (c) The bipy ligand is at an angle of 44.8° with respect to the layer comprised of Zn and IDS along the b-axis. Each successive layer of Zn and IDS along the c-axis is rotated by 180° with each bipy connection, leading to (d) an ABA stacking pattern. Carbon is gray, hydrogen is white, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, zinc1 is cyan, and zinc2 is yellow.

cln_elements.content: Network assignment of [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)], assigning the Zn atoms as the nodes and the IDS and the bipy linkages as edges. (a) The topological edges (orange) are overlaid upon the 2D layer outlined in Figure , leading to (b) the uninodal 36 layer designated hxl. The black atoms correspond to the Zn nodes. (c) Addition of the bipy edge in the structure leads to the network assignment of the 7-connected net ose.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Network assignment of [Zn2(IDS)(bipy)], assigning the Zn atoms as the nodes and the IDS and the bipy linkages as edges. (a) The topological edges (orange) are overlaid upon the 2D layer outlined in Figure , leading to (b) the uninodal 36 layer designated hxl. The black atoms correspond to the Zn nodes. (c) Addition of the bipy edge in the structure leads to the network assignment of the 7-connected net ose.

cln_elements.content: View of the Connolly surface of the channels along the [100] axis of 1 (top) and perpendicular to the [010] axis (bottom). The black spaces are open gaps within the structure. The framework atoms are shown in the space-filling style, and the calculated surface is highlighted in blue. The cavity and window are labeled in white. Carbon is gray, hydrogen is white, nitrogen is blue, oxygen is red, and zinc is purple.

cln_elements.content: “Void” atom, with the closest contacts to the framework highlighted by green bonds in the pore window, which has a cross section of 4 × 3 Å2 (left), and “void” atom cavity, with the closest contacts to the framework highlighted again by green bonds. The fictitious “void” atom is labeled green. All other atoms are labeled according to the color scheme in Figure a.

cln_elements.content: (a) TGA data for 1 measured in an N2 atmosphere. The weight loss of 8.82% between room temperature and 150 °C is attributed to the loss of the three water molecules which occupy the channels of 1. (b) PXRD pattern of 1 as-synthesized and after the guest water molecules have been removed by heating to 150 °C.

cln_elements.content: Adsorption isotherm of 1 measured at 195 K. The saturation of CO2 corresponds to a mass uptake of 12%, and the BET surface area was determined to be 183(7) m2 g−1.

metadata.title: Nanoporous Amino Acid Derived Material Formed via In-Situ Dimerization of Aspartic Acid
